{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2019}} {{for|the manufacturing in Canada of a similar name|Acadian (automobile)}} {{for|the sedan in Daewoo of a similar name|Daewoo Arcadia}} {{Infobox automobile | name = GMC Acadia | image = 2019 GMC Acadia Denali AWD, front 10.11.19.jpg | manufacturer = [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] ([[General Motors]]) | production = 2006–present | model_years = 2007–present | class =[[Full-size]] [[crossover SUV]] (2007–2017)
[[Mid-size]] [[crossover SUV]] (2017–) | body_style = 5-door [[sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | layout = [[FF layout|FF]] / [[All-wheel drive|AWD layout]] | transmission = 6-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | predecessor = [[GMC Envoy XL]]
[[GMC Safari]]
[[Isuzu Ascender]] (7-passenger version)
[[Pontiac Montana SV6]]
[[Saturn Outlook]]
[[Hummer H3]] (SUV version) }} The '''GMC Acadia''' is a midsize SUV from [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]]. The first-generation GMC Acadia shared the [[GM Lambda platform]] with the [[Chevrolet Traverse]], and [[Buick Enclave]]. The Acadia went on sale in 2006 as a 2007 model in the United States, Canada and Mexico. The Acadia replaces three of the 7- or 8-seater vehicles on the [[Pontiac]]–[[Buick]]–GMC dealership network, the [[mid-size|midsize]] [[Chevrolet Astro|GMC Safari]] [[van]], the [[GMC Envoy]], and the [[Pontiac Montana SV6]] [[minivan]] for the domestic market. As of 2009, the Lambda vehicles have replaced the [[Buick Rainier]], [[Buick Rendezvous]], [[Buick Terraza]], and the GMC Envoy XL and then subsequently the GMC Envoy, [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]] and the Isuzu Ascender A Denali version of the Acadia debuted in 2010 as a 2011 model. In 2016, the second generation Acadia was repositioned as a mid-size crossover utility vehicle (as a 2017 model) in order to compete within the growing midsize SUV market against the likes of the [[Ford Explorer]] and [[Dodge Durango]]. =={{Anchor|1}}First generation (2007–2016)== {{Infobox automobile | name = GMC Acadia | image = 07-GMC-Acadia.jpg | caption = Pre facelift GMC Acadia | production = 2006–2016 | model_years = 2007–2016 | assembly = {{ubl |United States: [[Spring Hill, Tennessee]] ([[Spring Hill Manufacturing]])}} | platform = [[GM Lambda platform]]/GMT968 (Series GMT960) | class = | engine = {{unbulleted list| 3.6 L [[GM High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]] [[V6 engine|V6]] | 3.6 L [[GM High Feature engine#LLT|LLT]] V6 }} | transmission = 6-speed [[GM-Ford 6-speed automatic transmission|6T75]] [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = {{convert|118.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{unbulleted list| 2007–2008 & 2013–2016: {{convert|201.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | 2009–2012: {{convert|200.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} | width = {{unbulleted list| 2007–2008 & 2013–2016: {{convert|78.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | 2009–2012: {{convert|78.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} | height = {{unbulleted list| 2007–2008 & 2013–2016: {{convert|72.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | 2009–2012: {{convert|69.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} | related = {{unbulleted list| [[Buick Enclave#1|Buick Enclave]] | [[Chevrolet Traverse#1|Chevrolet Traverse]] | [[Saturn Outlook]] }} }} The Acadia represents GMC's entry-level truck-like [[crossover (automobile)|CUV]] and is the first [[unibody]] vehicle from the marque. It is also GMC's first [[front-wheel drive]] passenger vehicle. The Acadia has seating for eight and either front or [[all-wheel drive]]. With a {{convert|5200|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} towing capacity, the Acadia slots between the [[GMC Terrain]] and the [[Chevrolet Tahoe|Yukon]]. The Acadia is the mid-priced Lambda model between the [[Chevrolet Traverse]] and Enclave. In December 2006, all production and sales of the Acadia (and the Saturn Outlook) were temporarily stopped due to the engine mounts not having holes drilled to release accumulated water, as well as an issue with potentially faulty rivets in the load floor just forward of the vehicle's rear hatch. The assembly process was quickly adjusted, and dealership sales of the vehicles had resumed within days of the notice. The first-generation Acadia was sold alongside its second-generation replacement as the Acadia Limited. ===Suspension and chassis=== The 2008 Acadia has a {{convert|118.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase and {{convert|67.28|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} front/rear tracks. The independent front suspension is a [[MacPherson strut]] design, with a direct-acting stabilizer bar and aluminum knuckles. The independent rear suspension uses a "H" Linked design. Steering is power-assisted rack-and-pinion, with an optional variable-effort system. Standard are 18 inch wheels and tires, with optional 19 inch wheels. Four-wheel [[disc brakes]] with [[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]] are standard. ===Engine and transmission=== The Acadia uses GM's [[GM High Feature engine|High Feature]] ''[[GM High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]]'' V6 that was introduced in the [[Cadillac CTS]]. In the Acadia, the engine produces {{convert|275|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|258|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The Acadia also uses the new [[GM-Ford 6-speed automatic transmission]]. The 2009 model year engine was the [[Direct fuel injection|direct injected]] ''[[GM High Feature engine#LLT|LLT]]'', producing {{convert|288|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|270|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The 2012 Acadia has a 3.6 L V6 engine producing {{convert|288|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 6,300 rpm and {{convert|270|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque at 3,400 rpm.{{Cite web|url=https://www.edmunds.com/gmc/acadia/2012/features-specs/|title=Used 2012 GMC Acadia Features & Specs {{!}} Edmunds|website=Edmunds|language=en|access-date=July 22, 2018}} The 2016 Acadia Limited has a 3.6 L V6 engine producing 310 hp (231 kW) and 271 lb ft (367 Nm) of torque{{Cite web|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/gm/gmc/acadia/2017-acadia/|title=2017 GMC Acadia|website=GM Authority|language=en-us|access-date=January 28, 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Year!!Engine!!Power!!Torque!!Transmission |- |2007–2008||3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]|| {{convert|275|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|251|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} || rowspan="2" |6-speed ''[[GM 6T75 transmission|6T75]]'' |- |2009–2016||3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LLT|LLT]]'' V6|| {{convert|288|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|270|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |- |2016 |3.6 L LGX V6 |310 hp (231 kW) |271 lb·ft (367 N·m) |6-speed 6T70 |} ===Interior=== The Acadia features available 3-row, 7 or 8-seater seating. Inside, the Acadia features more contemporary trim than the Outlook, including chrome and satin nickel textures, and a wider variety of two-toned interior colors such as an Ebony and Light Titanium (grey) cloth upholstery, and a choice of either Ebony, Light Titanium (grey) or Brick (brown) leather upholstery. A [[heads-up display]] similar to those found in the [[Cadillac XLR]], [[Cadillac STS]], [[Pontiac Grand Prix]], [[Pontiac Aztek]], [[Pontiac Bonneville]], [[Buick Park Avenue]] and [[Chevrolet Corvette]] is one of the available options exclusive to the Acadia and standard on the Acadia Denali thus far. ===Wheels and tires=== The 2008 Acadia features 19 inch cast aluminum wheels and Goodyear Eagle RS-A M+S P255/60R-19 108H tires with a high-pressure compact spare tire standard on the SLT2 model and optional on the SLT1. The SLE model has 18 inch painted aluminum wheels with P255/65R-18 tires. The SLT1 comes standard with 18 inch machined aluminum wheels. ===Acadia Denali=== [[File:GMC Acadia Denali -- 05-06-2011.jpg|thumb|First generation 2011 GMC Acadia Denali]] [[File:2013 GMC Acadia Denali -- 2012 NYIAS.JPG|thumb|221x221px|First generation refresh for 2013 GMC Acadia Denali]] The [[GMC Denali|Denali]] version of the Acadia arrived at dealerships in 2010 as 2011 model. This upgraded trim is available in FWD and AWD versions in seven- or eight-passenger form and features monotone paint, honeycomb grille, unique front and rear fascias, along with HID headlamps, chrome accents, exhaust tips, and six-spoke 20-inch wheels. Interior upgrades include perforated leather seating and wood trim. The Acadia Denali joins its SUV siblings, the [[GMC Terrain|Terrain]] Denali, the Yukon Denali and Yukon XL Denali, and marks GMC's first crossover to take the Denali badge.{{cite web|last=Filipponio |first=Frank |url= http://www.autoblog.com/2009/12/17/gmc-reveals-gussied-up-acadia-denali-for-2011/ |title=GMC reveals gussied-up Acadia Denali for 2011 |publisher=Autoblog |date=December 17, 2009 |accessdate=October 26, 2015}} ===Trim levels=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Trim level ! Years |- | SL | 2008–2012. ''' |- | SLE | 2007–present |- | SLT | 2007–present |- | Denali | 2011–present. |} ===Safety=== A [[Monocoque|unibody]] construction helps lower center of gravity, compared to previous truck-based GM SUVs, reduces the risk of rollover accidents. Much of the Acadia's structure is reinforced with high-strength steel, including a steel cross-car beam welded across the floor between the B-pillars. The Acadia has six different [[airbag]]s equipped in the vehicle; two dual-stage front air bags for the driver and front passenger, two seat-mounted side-impact air bags in the first row and two head curtain side impact air bags that cover all three seating rows. Similar to the [[Volvo XC90]], the Acadia will have a detection system on board that will deploy various airbags if a rollover is detected. Additionally, the Acadia comes standard with the [[OnStar]] system. ===Model year updates=== ====2013 facelift==== GM unveiled an updated 2013 GMC Acadia at the 2012 [[Chicago Auto Show]], taking the bodyshell of the discontinued [[Saturn Outlook]].{{cite web| url= http://suvs.about.com/od/gmc/ss/2013-Gmc-Acadia-Revealed-At-Chicago-Auto-Show.htm |title=2013 GMC Acadia Revealed at Chicago Auto Show |work=About.com |first=Jason |last=Fogelson |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2015}} The 2013 Acadia received a completely redesigned grille and front fascia, a redesigned rear liftgate, and an improved interior with upgrades to interior quality, as with its other two updated siblings, the [[Buick Enclave]] and [[Chevrolet Traverse]]. ====2014 model year==== For the 2014 model year, the Acadia added Forward Collision Alert and Lane Departure Warning as a standard on Denali and as an optional feature on SLT1 and SLT2 trims, while two charging-only USB ports on the rear of the center console for second-row use were added as a standard for all trims.{{cite press release|url= http://media.gmc.com/media/us/en/gmc/vehicles/acadia/2014.html |title=GMC Acadia - 2014 |publisher=GM Media |date=May 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2015}} ====2015 model year==== For the 2015 model year, a heated, leather-wrapped steering wheel became standard on SLT-2 and Denali models, along with a twenty-inch aluminum wheel design. Crimson Red Tintcoat, Dark Sapphire Blue Metallic, and Midnight Amethyst Metallic are added as new exterior color palettes. In addition, dual exhaust became available only on Denali versions, while all other trim levels received single exhaust.{{cite press release|url= http://media.gmc.com/media/us/en/gmc/vehicles/acadia/2015.html |title=GMC Acadia/Acadia Denali - 2015 |publisher=GM Media |date=August 2014 |accessdate=October 26, 2015}} {{clear}} =={{anchor|2}}Second generation (2017–present)== {{Infobox automobile | name = GMC Acadia | image = 2017 GMC Acadia front 3.23.18.jpg | aka = Holden Acadia (Australia/New Zealand) | production = 2016–present | model_years = 2017–present | assembly = {{ubl |United States: [[Spring Hill, Tennessee]] ([[Spring Hill Manufacturing]])}} | class = | platform = [[GM Epsilon platform#C1XX|C1XX]] | related = {{unbulleted list|[[Buick Enclave#2|Buick Enclave]] | [[Cadillac XT5#1|Cadillac XT5]] | [[Cadillac XT6]] | [[Chevrolet Blazer (crossover)|Chevrolet Blazer]] | [[Chevrolet Traverse#2|Chevrolet Traverse]] }} | engine = {{unbulleted list| 3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LGX|LGX]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] ([[gasoline]]) | 2.5 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LCV|LCV]]'' [[I4 engine|I4]] ([[gasoline]]) }} | transmission = 6-speed [[GM-Ford 6-speed automatic transmission|6T50/6T70]] [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2857|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | length = {{convert|193.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|75.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|68.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | predecessor = [[Holden Captiva]] (Australia and New Zealand) }} The second generation Acadia made its official debut at the [[North American International Auto Show]] on January 12, 2016. The redesigned Acadia went on sale in May 2016 as a 2017 model.[http://www.autonews.com/article/20160104/OEM03/301049919/high-end-vehicles-and-crossovers-will-take-center-stage-in-Motown "High End Vehicles And Crossovers Will Take Center Stage In Motown"] from Automotive News (January 9, 2016) The second generation Acadia is built in [[Spring Hill, Tennessee]]. [[File:2017 GMC Acadia rear 2.15.18.jpg|thumb|left|Rear view]] The second generation Acadia was reduced from 200.8 inches to 193.6 inches in length and from 78.9 inches to 75.4 inches in width (losing 700 pounds in the process), as GM repositioned the vehicle to mid-size status while remaining above the Terrain in size (the Terrain itself would relinquish its midsize status after it was repositioned as a second generation smaller compact crossover with the 2018 model), as GM has already announced that the next generation Traverse and Enclave will be the only GM-built full-size crossover SUVs in this segment. With the reduction from full-size to mid-size, the Acadia's MSRP was reduced to $29,995 (US).[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2016/02/2017-gmc-acadia-msrp-drops-between-1725-and-3000-over-2016-model-pricing-comparison/ "2017 GMC Acadia MSRP Drops Between $1,725 And $3,000 Over 2016 Model: Pricing Comparison"] from GM Authority (February 18, 2016) The GMC Acadia now has 5, 6, and 7 passenger configurations arranged respectively like either two front bucket seats and one rear bench seat; two bucket seats up front, two buckets in the second row, and two seats in the rear row; or two front bucket seats, one second row bench seat, and two rear seats in the third row. The second generation Acadia features seven seats instead of eight, a choice of either a 2.5L or 3.6L engine, a new advanced twin-clutch AWD system (available only with All-Terrain package) by [[GKN Driveline]] designed for off-road environment (joining the FWD and AWD drivetrains available on all other models), an updated fascia and redesigned lighting.[http://media.gmc.com/media/us/en/gmc/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2016/Jan/naias/gmc/0112-acadia.html GMC Introduces All-New 2017 Acadia] from GMC (January 12, 2016){{cite web|title=ACADIA ALL TERRAIN: TESTED OFF THE BEATEN PATH|url=http://www.gmc.com/gmc-life/suvs/testing-the-acadia-all-terrain|website=GMC|publisher=GM|accessdate=April 12, 2018}}{{cite web|title=2017 GMC Acadia: Our First Drive With The Latest From Professional Grade|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/2016/05/2017-gmc-acadia-our-first-drive-with-the-latest-from-professional-grade/|website=GM Authority|publisher=GM Authority|accessdate=April 12, 2018}} The Acadia is built on the same platform as the [[Cadillac XT5]] and will be joined by the Chinese-built [[Buick Envision]] and the [[Chevrolet Blazer (crossover)|Chevrolet Blazer]] (built on the C1XX platform) when GM unveils its lineup for its mid-size CUVs for 2018 and beyond.[http://www.autonews.com/article/20150720/OEM04/307209970/chevrolet-clears-space-for-a-new-crossover "Chevrolet Clears Space For A New Crossover"] from Automotive News (July 20, 2015)[https://www.autoblog.com/2018/02/28/chevy-blazer-midsize-suv-spy-photos/#slide-7259783 Is this a new Blazer? Chevy midsize SUV spied inside and out] from Autoblog (March 1, 2018) With the decrease in size, fuel economy with the 3.6L increases to 18 city, 25 hwy (AWD and FWD) from 17 city 24 hwy (FWD).{{cite web|title=FEATURES & SPECS|url=http://www.gmc.com/suvs/acadia-mid-size-suv/features-specs/trims.html|website=GMC|publisher=GM|accessdate=May 11, 2016}}{{cite web|title=FEATURES & SPECS|url=http://www.gmc.com/previous-year/acadia-mid-size-suv/features-specs/trims.html|website=GMC|publisher=GM|accessdate=May 11, 2016}} The 2017 Acadia will offer the newly launched AppShop feature.[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2016/06/2017-model-year-gm-vehicles-to-roll-out-long-awaited-app-shop/ "2017 Model Year GM Vehicles To Roll Out Long-Awaited App Shop"] from GM Authority (June 3, 2016) Trim levels for the second generation Acadia were carried over from the previous generation; '''SL''', '''SLE-1''', '''SLE-2''', '''SLT-1''', '''SLT-2''', as well as a '''Denali''' trim level, though an '''All-Terrain Package''' is available on Acadia SLE and SLT trim levels that will be more rugged in its appearance. The second generation Acadia is also available with Third Row Seat Delete option on SLE and SLT trim levels as part of the All-Terrain Package. The second generation Acadia introduced a feature to remind drivers to check the rear seats for children to help prevent heatstroke of children accidentally left behind in a vehicle.[http://www.autonews.com/article/20160112/OEM11/160119873/gm-unveils-technology-to-help-avoid-child-heatstroke-deaths "GM Unveils Technology To Help Avoid Child Heatstroke Deaths"] from ''Automotive News'' (January 12, 2016) ===Holden Acadia=== [[File:Holden Acadia Launch, 29 August 2018 (43429186695).jpg|left|thumb|Holden Acadia]] The Acadia is sold in Australia and New Zealand as a [[Holden]]-badged vehicle. It went on sale November 12, 2018. The Holden Acadia is built in Tennessee with RHD specifications, and is marketed as a full-size CUV.http://www.redbook.com.au/car-news/2016/car/holden/holden-confirms-captiva-replacement-103624?csn_tnet=true Australia and New Zealand are the only markets in the world where a right-hand drive version of the Acadia is sold. On 17 February 2020, GM announced that Holden brand will be phased out by 2021https://media.gm.com/media/au/en/holden/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/au/en/2020/feb/0217_Holden.html, but it is not yet known if the RHD Acadia will be rebranded or discontinued altogether. GM is looking at making vehicles like the Acadia become part of a “General Motors Specialty Vehicle” exporting sub-brand, as it already have Chevrolet brands (Camaro, Silverado, and Corvette) distributed through [[Holden Special Vehicles|a former Holden division]] since 2018. ===Acadia Limited=== For the 2017 model year, the first-generation Acadia was sold alongside its second-generation replacement, but was renamed the Acadia Limited, much like the [[Chevrolet Cruze|Chevrolet Cruze Limited]], [[Chevrolet Malibu|Chevrolet Malibu Limited]], and [[Chevrolet Impala|Chevrolet Impala Limited]] were also sold alongside their replacements, at least for a single model year, as rental and fleet vehicles. However, production remained in [[Lansing, Michigan]] as the second generation Acadia moved to [[Spring Hill, Tennessee]], the site of the original [[Saturn (automobile)|Saturn]] plant. With the second-generation [[Buick Enclave]] and [[Chevrolet Traverse]] making their debuts in 2017 as 2018 models, GMC ended production on the Acadia Limited on March 31, 2017 in order to start production on the Traverse and Enclave.[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2017/03/gmc-acadia-limited-production-scheduled-to-end-next-week/ "GMC Acadia Limited Production To End Next Week"] from GM Authority (March 24, 2017) The Acadia Limited carried a base price tag of $44,775 and continued to offer the same features from the 2016 model.[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2016/06/gmc-acadia-limited-priced-at-44775/ "GMC Acadia Limited Priced at $44,775"] from GM Authority (July 1, 2016) {{-}} ===Model year updates=== ====2020 facelift==== [[File:2020 GMC Acadia AT4 front NYIAS 2019.jpg|thumb]] [[File:2020 GMC Acadia AT4 rear NYIAS 2019.jpg|thumb]] The [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] Acadia received a facelift for 2020. The facelift introduced new exterior styling (including a new front grille inspired by the all-new 2019 [[GMC Sierra]] 1500), a revised infotainment system with [[Apple CarPlay]] and [[Android Auto]] [[smartphone]] integration, new alloy wheel options, an all-new '''AT4''' trim level (which replaces the All-Terrain Package on select trim levels), a new 2.0L turbocharged [[EcoTec]] inline four-cylinder (I4) engine (both the 2.5L EcoTec I4 and 3.6L VVT V6 engine options remain available for 2020), and the Electronic Precision Shift push-button automatic transmission that was first introduced on the 2018 [[GMC Terrain]], among other changes. The 2020 GMC Acadia went on sale in the fall of 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a26358738/2020-gmc-acadia-suv-photos-info/|title=The 2020 GMC Acadia Looks Blockier and Has a New Turbo Engine|work=[[Car and Driver]]|last=Capparella|first=Joey|date=18 February 2019|accessdate=18 February 2019}} {{clear}} ==Yearly US sales== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! {{More citations needed|date=July 2018}}{{Infobox automobile |name=GMC Syclone |image=1991GMCSyclone.jpg |production=1991
(2,995 produced) |manufacturer=[[General Motors]] |related=[[GMC Typhoon]]
[[GMC Jimmy]]/[[Chevrolet S-10 Blazer]]
[[GMC Sonoma]]/[[Chevrolet S-10]]
[[Oldsmobile Bravada]] |engine= 4.3 L ''[[General Motors 90° V6 engine#Turbocharged LB4 4.3L V6|LB4]]'' [[turbocharger|turbo]] [[V6]]{{cite magazine | title=Smokin' Syclone| url=http://www.hemmings.com| magazine=Hemmings Motor News| author=Jeff Koch| accessdate=January 31, 2006}} |transmission=4-speed ''[[Turbo-Hydramatic#THM700R4 / 4L60 / 4L60E / 4L65E / 4L70E|4L60]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] |wheelbase={{convert|108.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length={{convert|180.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|64.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height={{convert|60.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |layout=[[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, four-wheel-drive]] }} The '''GMC Syclone''' is a high-performance version of the [[GMC Sonoma]] [[pickup truck]]. Produced in 1991 by [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]], the Syclone spawned the similarly powered 1992-1993 [[GMC Typhoon]] [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]]. Another vehicle, the [[Sonoma GT|GMC Sonoma GT]], offered less performance but was seen as a companion model. ==Product run== At the time it was introduced, the Syclone was the quickest stock pickup truck being produced in the world. Auto magazines compared its acceleration favorably to a variety of sports cars including the Corvette and - in a memorable comparison test in ''Car and Driver'' magazine - a Ferrari.{{cite web | url=http://www.sportmachines.com/wiki/tiki-index.php?page=Car+and+Driver+Sept+1991&bl=y| title=Car and Driver Sept 1991| work=sportmachines.com}} It features a turbocharged 6-cylinder engine, all wheel drive and 4-wheel anti-lock brakes. Both the Syclone and Typhoon trucks feature a [[Mitsubishi]] TD06-17C 8 cm² [[turbocharger]] and [[Garrett AiResearch|Garrett]] water/air [[intercooler]] attached to a 4.3 L ''[[Chevrolet 90-Degree V6 engine#Turbocharged LB4 4.3L V6|LB4]]'' [[V6]] engine with unique pistons, main caps, head gaskets, [[intake manifold]]s, fuel system, [[exhaust manifold]]s, and a 48mm twin bore throttle body from the 5.7 L [[GM Small-Block engine]]. All Syclones and Typhoons had a [[Turbo-Hydramatic#THM700R4 / 4L60 / 4L60E / 4L65E / 4L70E|4L60]] 4-speed [[automatic transmission]]. A [[BorgWarner]] all wheel drive transfer case splits torque with 35% forward and 65% to the rear wheels. Both trucks featured sport modifications to the standard suspensions. The Syclone was the first production truck to receive a 4-wheel [[anti-lock braking system]].{{cite web |last1=Huizenga |first1=Paul |title=Storm on the Horizon: Tracing Today's Super SUV Origins |url=https://www.drivingline.com/articles/storm-on-the-horizon-tracing-todays-super-suv-origins/ |website=Driving Line |publisher=Nitto Tire |accessdate=19 December 2019}} With this engine, the Syclone produces {{Convert|280|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|350|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} of torque. The Syclone, when new, was capable of accelerating from 0-60 mph (97 km/h) in 4.3 seconds and could do a quarter-mile run in 13.4 seconds at {{Convert|98|mph|km/h|0|abbr=on}} according to Car & Driver's comparison test. In 1991 Syclones were only available in black. 1992 models were to be offered in a wider range of colors before they were canceled. Two thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five Syclones were built in 1991, and three in 1992. One hundred and thirteen (estimated 31 returned) were reported as Export Sales including a subset now referred to as the ''Saudi Syclones'' — a small number were delivered to [[Saudi Arabia]] and modified with a metric dash cluster, leaded fuel chip, and a [[Resonator#Automobiles|resonator]] in place of the [[catalytic converter]]. The Syclone, Typhoon, and Sonoma GT were built for GMC by [[Production Automotive Services]] of [[Troy, Michigan]], and sold through dealerships. The Syclone and Typhoon's gauge cluster is the one used in the [[Pontiac Sunbird]] Turbo, which was discontinued in 1990, one year before the Syclone was introduced. In 2009, a poor-condition GMC Syclone was scrapped under the [[Car Allowance Rebate System]], despite being highly collectible,{{cite news|url=http://jalopnik.com/5462441/morons-clunkerize-rare-gmc-syclone-super-truck|title=Morons Clunkerize Rare GMC Syclone Super Truck|publisher=[[Jalopnik]] |date= Feb 2, 2010 |accessdate=2010-02-02}} although it was saved by a group of auto enthusiasts.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ==Special editions== There were two special-edition 1991 Syclones offered by third parties: ===Marlboro Syclone=== {{Infobox automobile |name=Marlboro Syclone |production=10 conversions |image=1991GMCMarlboro.jpg }} The special-edition [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]] Syclone was the grand prize for the ten winners of The Marlboro Racing ‘92 Contest. All ten trucks were provided to [[American Sunroof Company]] (ASC), by Shinoda Design Associates, Inc., in conjunction with Phillip Morris, Inc. With the help of [[Larry Shinoda]], designer of the Corvette Stingray and Boss Mustang, a transformation of the originally black Syclones took place. Marlboro Syclone custom features include: *ASC converted the roof to a targa-style{{What?|date=April 2017}} roof panel with mounts in the pick-up bed *ASC installed a slide-down rear window assembly *Guidon hard [[tonneau]] cover *[[Boyd Coddington]] "Cobra" wheels with Marlboro emblem center caps and Goodyear Eagle GS-C tires *PPG "Hot Licks" Red paint, with white strobe stripes provided by Graphik Concepts *[[Recaro]] leather seats with Simpson 5-Point racing harness *Custom [[Momo (company)|MOMO]] "Evolution" steering wheel *Sony sound system *PROMPaq performance chip and Borla [[stainless steel]] exhaust *Bell Tech suspension which lowered the truck by three inches ===Indy Syclone=== Three ''Indy Syclones'' were used at the [[Indianapolis 500]] race on May 24, 1992 with the only modifications being a sticker package. One of these Indy trucks was converted into the [[PPG Industries|PPG]] ''Syclone Pace Truck'' (though it was not the [[List of Indianapolis 500 pace cars|official pace car]]) with significant modifications, including a multi-colored silver, magenta, and aqua paint scheme, and a molded in light bar in the roof, a [[racing fuel cell]] and fire system. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|GMC Syclone}} *[http://www.sytyregistry.com/ International SyTy Registry Forum] *[http://www.sportmachines.com/ Syclone, Typhoon, Sonoma GT Database & History] *[http://www.sportmachines.net/ Syclone, Typhoon, Sonoma GT Restoration & Parts] {{GMC}} [[Category:GMC vehicles|Syclone]] [[Category:Pickup trucks]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

{{about|the GMC 'Jimmy' World War II "Deuce-and-a-half"|its successor|M35 2½-ton cargo truck|2½-ton, 6x6, U.S. military trucks in general|2½-ton 6x6 truck}} {{Infobox weapon |name=CCKW | image= GMC 2 Half-ton 6x6 Truck.jpg | image_size = 300 |caption=CCKW 353 cargo truck with winch |origin= United States |type={{frac|2|1|2}}-ton 6×6 Cargo truck |is_vehicle=yes |is_UK= |service= |used_by= |wars= |designer=Yellow Truck and Coach Co. |design_date = 1941 |manufacturer = Yellow/GMC Truck and Coach
Chevrolet |production_date = 1941–45 |number = '''Grand Total:''' ~572,500
including all variants;
'''CCKW specific:''' ~518,000
— '''LWB CCKW-353:''' ~464,000 and
— '''SWB CCKW-352:''' ~54,000 units
plus ~54,500 non CCKW variants |variants = '''1939 ACKWX''' – 2,466 units
'''C.O.E. AFKWX''' – 7,235 units
'''6x4 CCW-353''' – 23,649 units
'''DUKW amphibs''' – 21,147 units |spec_label=353 Cargo w/winch{{sfnp|TM 9-801|1944|pp=6-9, 16-19}} |weight={{convert|8,800|lb|abbr=on}} empty
{{convert|16,400|lb|abbr=on}} loaded |length= {{convert|270+1/8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} |width= {{convert|88|in|m|2|abbr=on}} |height={{convert|93|in|m|2|abbr=on}} to cab
{{convert|109+1/8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} overall |crew= |armour= |primary_armament= |secondary_armament= |engine = [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#270|GMC 270 straight-6]] |engine_power = {{convert|91.5|hp|kW|abbr=on}} at 2,750 rpm {{sfnp |ref=TM9280047 |TM 9-2800 'MILITARY VEHICLES' |1947 |p=267–270, 272–279 }} or {{convert|104|hp|kW|abbr=on}} at 2,750 rpm {{sfnp |ref=TM9280043 |TM 9-2800 'Standard Military Motor Vehicles' |1943 |p=238–275 }} |transmission=5 spd. x 2 range trf. case |suspension=Beam axles on leaf springs |fuel_capacity={{convert|40|USgal|l|abbr=on}} |vehicle_range={{convert|300|mi|km|1|abbr=on}} |speed={{convert|45|mph|abbr=on}} }} [[File:Jour d'la Libéthâtion Jèrri 9 d'Mai 2011 100.jpg|thumb|304px|Restored CCKW 353 Cargo truck with open cab, machine gun ring, and front-mounted winch]] The '''[[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] CCKW''', also known as '''"Jimmy"''', or the [[List of U.S. military vehicles by supply catalog designation#G500 to G599|{{nobr|'''G-508'''}}]] by its Ordnance Supply Catalog nr,The [[Ordnance Corps (United States Army)|U.S. Army Ordnance Corps]] Supply Catalog designation, 'G-number', or SNL nr. — a group number for ordering parts, based on a [[List of U.S. Army weapons by supply catalog designation|Standard Nomenclature List]]. was a highly successful series of [[Off-road vehicle|off-road capable]], [[2½-ton 6x6 truck|2{{1/2}}-ton, 6x6 trucks]], built in large numbers to a standardized design (from 1941 to 1945) for the [[U.S. Army]], that saw heavy service, predominantly as cargo trucks, in both [[World War II]] and the [[Korean War]]. The original "Deuce and a Half", it formed the backbone of the famed [[Red Ball Express]] that kept [[World War II allies|Allied]] armies supplied as they pushed eastward after the [[Normandy invasion]].{{sfnp|Colley|2000}} The CCKW came in many variants, including open or closed cab, long wheelbase (LWB) '''CCKW-353''' and short (SWB) '''CCKW-352''', and over a score of specialized models, but the bulk were standard, general purpose, cargo models. A large minority were built with a front mounted winch, and one in four of the cabs had a machine-gun mounting ring above the co-driver's position. Of the almost 2.4 million trucks that the U.S. Army bought between 1939 and December 1945, across all payload weight classes, some 812,000, or just over one third, were {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton trucks.''(Or 5-ton on-road rated)''{{cite book |last=Hyde |first=Charles K. |year=2013 |title=Arsenal of Democracy: The American Automobile Industry in World {{nobr|War II}} |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=P-PCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA152 |location= |publisher=Wayne State University Press |page=152–154 |isbn=9780814339527 |author-link= |ref=HydeArsfn }} GMC's total production of the CCKW and its variants, including the 2{{1/2}}-ton, 6x6, amphibian [[DUKW]], and the 6x4, 5-ton (on-road) CCW-353, amounted to some 572,500 units – almost a quarter of the total WW II U.S. truck production, and 70 percent of the total {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton trucks. GMC's total of ~550,000 purely 6x6 models, including the DUKW, formed the overwhelming majority of the ~675,000 six by six {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton trucks, and came in less than 100,000 shy of the almost 650,000 [[Willys MB|World War II jeeps]]. Additionally, GM built over 150,000 units of the CCKW's smaller brother, the {{frac|1|1|2}}-ton, 4x4 [[Chevrolet G506]], at the same factory. The GMC CCKW began to be phased out, once the [[M35 series 2½-ton 6x6 cargo truck|M35 series trucks]] were first deployed in the 1950s, but remained in active U.S. service until the mid-1960s. Eventually, the M35 series, originally developed by [[REO Motor Car Company|REO Motors]], succeeded the CCKW as the U.S. Army's standard {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton, 6x6 cargo truck. ==Etymology== The name '''CCKW''' comes from GMC model [[nomenclature]]:{{sfnp|Whitlock|2004}} * '''"C"''', designed in 1941 * '''"C"''', conventional cab * '''"K"''', all-wheel drive * '''"W"''', dual rear axles * '''"X"''', experimental chassis / non-standard wheelbase (first 13,188 units ) ==History== In 1939-1940 the [[Ordnance Corps (United States Army)|US Army Ordnance Corps]] was developing {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton (2,268 kg) load-rated [[six-wheel drive|6×6]] tactical trucks that could operate off-road in all weather. General Motors, already supplying modified commercial trucks to the Army, modified the 1939 ACKWX – built for the French Army – into the CCKW.{{sfnp|Ware|2010|pp=238-239}} The General Motors design was chosen by the Army and went into production at GM'S [[Yellow Coach Manufacturing Company|Yellow Truck and Coach]] division's [[Pontiac Assembly|Pontiac, Michigan plant]] alongside 6×4 CCWs. Later they were also manufactured at [[St. Louis Truck Assembly|GM's St. Louis, Missouri Chevrolet plant]].{{sfnp|Crismon|2001|pp=9, 184, 326, 330-335, 465}}{{sfnp|Doyle|2010|p=9}} ==Production numbers== Sources do not precisely agree on the total numbers of CCKWs built by the end of production in 1945. Ware (2010) lists one single number of 562,750 of CCKW trucks, built across all variants – presumably including the amphibian DUKW. More clearly specified numbers are provided by Sunderlin in ''Army Motors'' magazine, and by Jackson, using the numbers found in the 1946 revision of the U.S. military's ''Summary Report of Acceptances, Tank-Automotive Materiel''. Sunderlin reports a total of 528,829 of {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton 6x6 units (excluding the DUKW) produced by GMC — versus a total of 527,168 accepted by the U.S. Army.{{cite magazine |last=Sunderlin |first=Bryce |date= |title=THE JIMMY's ANCESTRY – The CCKW in Detail and The Collector's Syndrome |url=http://www.cckw.org/pdf/CCKW_Part_1.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185616/http://www.cckw.org/pdf/CCKW_Part_1.pdf |archive-date=2016-03-04 |magazine=Army Motors |location=Lansing, MI |publisher=CCKW.org |access-date=2019-04-10 |pages=19–22 }} Jackson's tabulation of the 1946 U.S. acceptances numbers adds up to 524,873 units, excluding the DUKWs and the ACKWX predecessor models.{{cite web |url=http://usautoindustryworldwartwo.com/General%20Motors/gmc.htm |title=The American Automobile Industry in World War Two – GMC |last=Jackson |first=David |date=1 February 2019 |website= |publisher= |access-date=2019-04-10 |quote=}}{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|pages=86–102}} Both of these numbers still include the cab-over engine AFKWX-353 models — leaving a total of some 518,000–519,000 actual CCKW-352 and CCKW-353 units. In addition, GMC serial numbers indicate a production of 23,500 of the same bodied 6x4 CCW models, versus 23,649 units accepted by U.S. ordnance. In any case, GM / GMC built a total of {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton, 6-wheeled trucks that was second only to the [[Willys MB|WW II “Jeep”]] {{sfnp|Ware|2010|pp=238-239}} — and neither Ford nor Willys individually built as many jeeps during the war. ==Specifications== ===Engine and drive-line=== The CCKW was equipped with the [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#270|GMC 270 engine]], an overhead valve inline-6 with {{convert|91.5|hp|kW|abbr=on}} {{sfnp |ref=TM9280047 |TM 9-2800 'MILITARY VEHICLES' |1947 |p=267–270, 272–279 }} or {{convert|104|hp|kW|abbr=on}} {{sfnp |ref=TM9280043 |TM 9-2800 'Standard Military Motor Vehicles' |1943 |p=238–275 }} at 2750rpm, and {{convert|216|lbft|0}} at 1400rpm.{{sfnp |ref=TM9280047 |TM 9-2800 'MILITARY VEHICLES' |1947 |p=267–270, 272–279 }} A {{convert|3+25/32|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} bore by {{convert|4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} stroke gave a {{convert|269.5|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} displacement.{{sfnp|TM 9-801|1944|pp=6-9}} This (gasoline) engine was designed for commercial trucks, and was reliable in service.{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=108-118}} The transmission was a Warner T93 5-speed with a direct 4th gear and overdrive 5th gear. The transfer case had high and low gears, and engaged the front axle. Originally all axles were a Timken split type, later trucks also used GM "banjo" types.{{sfnp|TM 9-801|1944|pp=13-14, 35-39}}{{sfnp|Doyle|2010|pp=9, 10, 20}} ===Chassis=== The CCKW had a ladder frame chassis with three driven beam axles, the front on leaf springs, the rear tandem on leaf springs with locating arms. There were two wheelbases, the short Model 352 and the long Model 353. The short, {{convert|145|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} (Measurements are from the centerline of the front axle to the centerline of rear bogie) was used with a short cargo bed as an artillery prime mover for 75 mm and 105 mm howitzers. All other models used the long {{convert|164|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase. Tires were 7.50-20, brakes were hydraulic with vacuum assist.{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=108-118}} Some were fitted with {{convert|10000|lb|abbr=on}} front-mounted winches. A winch added {{convert|300|lb}} and {{convert|14|in|cm|0}}.{{sfnp|TM 9-801|1944|pp=17-18, 54-58}} Some open cab chassis were cut in half behind the cab for air transport. Each half was a load, at the vehicle's destination, the halves were bolted back together.{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=108-118}}{{sfnp|Doyle|2010|pp=47-55}} ==Versions== [[File:K-53 shop van.jpg|thumb|Van body with canvas roof and doors in place]] [[File:GMC CCKW 750 Gal Tanker.jpg|thumb|Gasoline tanker ({{convert|750|usgal|l|abbr=on}})]] [[File:G-508 GMC CCKW-353-B2 with m55 Machine-gun mount pic3.JPG|thumb|right|CCKW-353-B2 [[gun truck]] with [[M45 Quadmount|M45]] Quadmount on M20 trailer in bed, loading ramps attached to side]] Initially, all versions used a modified commercial closed cab design having a metal roof and doors. By 1944 an open cab version, with a canvas roof and doors, was used. This was easier to build, and the roof could be removed to lower the shipping height. 1 in 4 of cabs had a machine gun mounting ring above the co-driver's position.{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=108-118}} The CCKW provided a platform for the widest range of bodies on any U.S. military vehicle,{{cn|date=April 2019}} with the {{convert|12|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} cargo version being the most common. As steel was more heavily rationed during the course of the war, the steel cargo bed was replaced by a wooden one. Wooden beds proved unsatisfactory and a 'composite' bed with steel sides, framing, and wooden bottom slats was developed.{{sfnp|Doyle|2010|p=9}} However, the composite bed was still unsatisfactory and the bed design returned to all steel. Standard cargo models had beds with fixed sides and a drop tailgate, as well as folding troop seats. A standard rectangular van configuration was used in communications, medical, workshop, and many other specialty roles. Special built vans were also used.{{sfnp|Doyle|2010|pp=78-80}} ===Specialized variants=== Many specialized variants of the basic 6×6 CCKW were made, some in small numbers, including some converted in the field. These include:{{sfnp|TM 9-2800|1947|pp=267-268, 272-293}} * Air compressor * Bomb service * Chemical decontaminating * Chemical handling * Dental operating van * Dump truck * Fire engine * Fuel & gas tankers ({{convert|750|usgal|l|abbr=on}}) * Fuel & oil handling ({{convert|660|usgal|l|abbr=on}}), ({{convert|750|usgal|l|abbr=on}}) * High lift * K-53 radio equip. van * K-60 radio equip. van * Map reproduction van * Ordnance maintenance van * Pipeline equipment * Ponton bolster * Semi-trailer tractor{{cite web |url=http://www.surfacezero.com/g503/showphoto.php?photo=81664&title=gmc-cckw-tractor&cat=2222 |title=GMC CCKW Tractor |website=The G503 Album |access-date=8 August 2017}} * Shop equipment GP repair van * Surgical van * Water purification van * Water tanker ({{convert|700|usgal|l|abbr=on}}) * Welder's truck ===ACK-353=== The ACK-353 ('''A''' for 1939 design, '''C''' for conventional cab, and '''K''' for all wheel drive) {{frac|1|1|2}}-ton 4x4 truck was the smaller brother of the ACKWX, and a predecessor to the [[Chevrolet G506]], competing with the [[Dodge WC series#1940 — 1⁄2-ton VC and 1 1⁄2-ton VF models|Dodge / Fargo T-203 / VF-400]] series, as GM was at that time also trying to clinch the lucrative contract for the standard World War II cargo trucks in the {{frac|1|1|2}}-ton 4x4 category.{{cite book |last=Doyle |first=David |year=2019 |title=Chevrolet G-506 – {{frac|1|1|2}}-ton 4x4 Development, Production and Variants in WW2 |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190408104402/https://cdn3.volusion.com/hrqpw.cruld/v/vspfiles/photos/620-1000-5.jpg |location=Branchville, NJ |publisher=Portrayal Press |page=8 |isbn=9780938242062 |author-link=David Doyle (writer) }} The ACK-353 was equipped with the new for 1939 [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#248|GMC 248 engine]], an overhead valve, low-deck inline-six with a {{convert|3+23/32|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} bore and {{convert|3+13/16|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} stroke, resulting in a {{convert|248|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} displacement, producing {{convert|77|bhp|kW}} (net).[http://69.5.4.225/od_mvg_vehicle_id_ltrucks.php Military Light Trucks – Olive-Drab]{{cite book |last=Vanderveen |first=Bart |year=1972 |title=Observer's Fighting Vehicle Directory, WW II |url=https://olive-drab.com/images/id_gmc_ack353_full.jpg |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103073751/https://olive-drab.com/images/id_gmc_ack353_full.jpg |archivedate=2018-03-03 |url-status=live |location=London |publisher=[[Frederick Warne & Co|F. Warne]] |isbn=978-0723214694 }} Transmission was four-speed manual, combined with a two-speed transfer-case engaging the front axle for all-wheel drive operation. The truck rode on a {{convert|157+3/4|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase, measuring {{convert|256|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|90|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} wide, and {{convert|117|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} tall – or {{convert|89|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} with the rear top bows taken down. Tires were 7.50-20, and weight came in at {{convert|7532|lb|abbr=on}}. A special feature were the front hubs, designed to take dual wheels in especially challenging terrain. Fitted with steel GS bodies with fixed sides and troop seats, the trucks were originally ordered under French contract, but ended up in use by the British Army, although some 2,000 units delivered to the French in early 1940 likely fell into the hands of the Nazi Germany [[Wehrmacht]].[https://www.o5m6.de/wehrmacht_old/gmc_ack353.html Engines of the Wehrmacht – GMC ACK-353, 1.5-ton, 4x4, Cargo Truck] ===ACKWX-353=== The ACKWX-353 ('''A''' for 1939 design, '''C''' for conventional cab, '''K''' for all wheel drive, '''W''' for tandem rear axles, and '''X''' for non-standard chassis) three-ton 6x6 truck was the direct predecessor from which the CCKW was developed. Fitted with the same {{convert|77|bhp|kW}} drivetrain as the ACK, the trucks weighed {{convert|9856|lb|abbr=on}}, and measured {{convert|264|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, {{convert|94.5|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} wide, and {{convert|118|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} tall / or {{convert|90|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} to cab.{{cite book |last=Vanderveen |first=Bart |year=1972 |title=Observer's Fighting Vehicle Directory, WW II |url=https://olive-drab.com/idphoto/id_photos_gmc_h_early.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917150703/https://olive-drab.com/images/id_gmc_ackwx353_full.jpg |archivedate=2018-03-03 |url-status=live |location=London |publisher=[[Frederick Warne & Co|F. Warne]] |isbn=978-0723214694 }} [[File:G-508_Cargo_17_FT_Body_GMC_AFKWX-353_C.O.E._pic1.JPG|thumb|GMC AFKWX-353 cab-over-engine]] Some 1,000 of the 3-ton 6x6 trucks were originally contracted by France, but – just like the 4x4 ACK trucks – after the defeat of the French, diverted to Britain in 1940. The British however, deemed the trucks unfavorable for use in the war, due to their long wheelbase and lacking power, and diverted them to Russia in turn, in 1941.[https://www.o5m6.de/redarmy_old/gmc_ackwx353.html Engines of the Red Army in WW2 – GMC ACKWX-353] A total of 2,466 ACKWX trucks were built — both according to GMC's serial numbers, as well as the U.S. Army's acceptance figures. ===AFKWX-353=== The AFKWX ('''A''' for 1939 design, '''F''' for forward cab, '''K''' for all wheel drive, '''W''' for tandem rear axles, and '''X''' for non-standard chassis) 353, a [[cab over|cab over engine]], long cargo bed version of the CCKW, went into production alongside it in 1942 at Yellow’s Pontiac plant and Chevrolet’s in St. Louis. Otherwise mechanically identical, its compact cabin design allowed a {{convert|15|ft|m|2|abbr=on}}, and later {{convert|17|ft|m|2|abbr=on}} cargo bed to be fitted. Only the first 50 units produced had closed cabs, all others were open. None had a front-mounted winch. The [[cab over]] design made engine maintenance difficult. As a result, only 7,235 were built,{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=105-107}}{{sfnp|TM 9-2800|1947|pp=268-269}} – 2,232 units with the 15 ft. body, and 5,000 of the 17 ft. version. [[Image:DUKW.image2.army.jpg|thumb|right|DUKW in use by American troops in France]] ===CCW-353=== The CCW-353 ('''C''' for 1941 design, '''C''' for conventional cab, and '''W''' for tandem rear axles) was a near identical version of the CCKW-353, that lacked its front-wheel drive, resulting in an officially purely on-road, and therefore 5-ton rated, 6×4 version of the same truck. A beam front axle was used, with the transfer case locked in high range. Of the ~118,000 {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton, 6x4 trucks the U.S. built in WW II, GMC contributed 23,649 units of the CCW-353 as standard cargo trucks without winch – almost all of them built in 1942.[http://usautoindustryworldwartwo.com/General%20Motors/gmc.htm The American Automobile Industry in World War Two – GMC (2-1-2019)] ===DUKW=== {{Main|DUKW}} The DUKW ('''D''' for 1942 design, '''U''' for utility, '''K''' for all wheel drive, and '''W''' for tandem rear axles) — popularly the “Duck” – was an amphibious truck that shared the CCKW's driveline, but had a totally different body and structure than all the other trucks. First produced at Yellow’s Pontiac plant, as demand increased production was added to Chevrolet’s St. Louis plant. The hull, designed by an [[America's Cup]] winner, gave the truck respectable sea-keeping capability. A very successful design, 21,147 were built.{{sfnp|TM 9-801|1944|pp=465}}{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=119-121}}{{sfnp|ref=SRATAM4045|Summary Report – Tank-Automotive Materiel|1945|page=86}} ==Gallery== File:CCKW-rhine.jpg|[[80th Division (United States)|80th Division]] crossing the Rhine near Mainz File:Convoy Red Ball Express.jpg|[[Red Ball Express]] convoy, 1944 File:G-508 6x6 GMC CCKW-353-2 Air Compressor truck pic1.JPG|Restored maintenance vehicle File:GMC Airportable3.JPG|Restored two part chassis for air transport ==See also== {{colbegin}} * [[2½-ton 6x6 truck|2{{1/2}}-ton, 6x6 truck {{Distinguish|Chevrolet Chevette|Vauxhall Chevette}}{{Infobox automobile | name = GMC Chevette | image = GMC Chevette.JPG | caption = GMC Chevette 2 door sedan | manufacturer = [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]] ([[General Motors]]) | production = 1992-1995 | model_years = | assembly = [[Brazil]] | predecessor = [[Opel K 180]] | successor = [[Opel Corsa|Chevrolet Corsa]] | class = | body_style = 2 door sedan
4 door sedan | engine = 1.6L
1.7L diesel }} The '''GMC Chevette''' is an [[automobile]] which was manufactured from 1992 to 1995 by [[General Motors do Brasil]] specifically for the [[Argentina|Argentinian]] market, where it was sold by both [[Chevrolet]] and [[Renault]] dealers.{{cite web | url = http://vauxpedianet.uk2sitebuilder.com/vauxhall-t-car---opel-k180-gmc-chevette-argentina | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171116175010/http://vauxpedianet.uk2sitebuilder.com/vauxhall-t-car---opel-k180-gmc-chevette-argentina | archivedate = 2017-11-16 | title = Vauxhall T car - Opel K180 & GMC Chevette in Argentine | work = vauxpedianet }} This was the result of a deal having been made whereby Argentinian [[Renault Argentina|CIADEA]]-made [[Renault Trafic]]s were sold as "Chevrolets" in Brazil in return for GM do Brasil being allowed to export Chevettes to Argentina. The Chevette was a variation of the [[GM T platform (1973)|General Motors T-car]] platform which includes [[Opel Kadett#Kadett C .281973.E2.80.931979.29|Opel Kadett]], [[Chevrolet Chevette]] and [[Isuzu Gemini#1974|Isuzu Gemini]]. Offered as a 2-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] and as a 4-door sedan, it was powered by a 1.6-liter [[overhead camshaft]] engine with a 1.8-liter [[Isuzu]] diesel engine available as an option. A [[Pickup truck|pickup]] version of the Chevette was sold as the '''Chevrolet 500'''. The Chevette was the only sedan car to be badged as a [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]]. (In North America, the GMC brand solely marketed light duty and heavy duty trucks until the late 2000s when the company added crossovers.)[https://www.carthrottle.com/post/2zlz444/ GMC Chevette. The only one passenger car sold under the GMC brand] - Retrieved on 03/17/2018 It was replaced in the Argentinian market by the [[Chevrolet Corsa]] in 1995. ==See also== * [[Vauxhall Chevette]] * [[Chevrolet Chevette]] * [[Chevrolet Chevette|Pontiac T1000]] * [[Daewoo Maepsy]] * [[Opel Kadett#Kadett C (1973–1979)|Opel Kadett C]] * [[Vauxhall Astra]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:GMC vehicles|Chevette]] [[Category:1990s cars]] {{GMC timeline 1980 to present}}{{Modern-auto-stub}}

{{Infobox automobile | name = GMC Typhoon | image = 92typhoon.jpg | production = 1991–1993
4697 produced | manufacturer = [[General Motors]] | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | body_style = 2-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | related = [[GMC Syclone]]
[[GMC Jimmy]]/[[Chevrolet S-10 Blazer|Chevrolet Blazer]]
[[GMC Sonoma]]/[[Chevrolet S-10]]
[[Oldsmobile Bravada]] | engine = 4.3 L Turbocharged V-6 | transmission = 4-speed ''[[Turbo-Hydramatic#THM700R4 / 4L60 / 4L60E / 4L65E / 4L70E|4L60]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = 100.5 in (2553 mm) | length = 170.3 in (4326 mm) | width = 68.2 in (1732 mm) | height = 60.0 in (1524 mm) | weight = 3822 lb (1734 kg) | layout = [[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, four-wheel-drive]] }} The '''GMC Typhoon''' is a high-performance [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]], produced from 1991 to 1993 by [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]]. The Typhoon was based on the 1991 [[Chevrolet S-10 Blazer|GMC Jimmy]].{{cite journal|journal=[[Car and Driver]]|volume= 37| number= 9|date= March 1992 |pages= 63–67| title=Road Test: GMC Typhoon| first= Arthur |last= St. Antoine | url= http://sportmachines.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Car-Driver-3-92.pdf| access-date= July 6, 2017}} ==Description== Like the [[GMC Syclone]], the Typhoon is powered by a 4.3 L LB4 V6 engine with unique pistons, main caps, head gaskets, intake manifolds, fuel system, exhaust manifolds, and a 48mm twin bore throttle body from the 5.7 L GM Small-Block engine. With this engine, the Syclone produces {{Convert|280|hp|0|abbr=on}} and 350 lb⋅ft (475 N⋅m) of torque. The engine is a modified version of the Vortec engine found in the standard Jimmy, which originally produced {{Convert|190|hp|0|abbr=on}}.{{Cite news|url=https://www.streetmusclemag.com/features/car-features/musclecars-you-should-know-gmcs-turbo-terrors-typhoon-and-syclone/|title=Muscle Cars You Should Know: GMC Typhoon / Syclone|date=2016-09-19|work=Street Muscle|access-date=2018-07-25|language=en-US}} The engine uses a Mitsubishi TD06-17C/8 cm2 [[turbocharger]] producing 14 psi of boost and a [[Garrett AiResearch|Garrett]] Water/Air [[intercooler]], as well as revised [[intake manifold]]s, fuel system, exhaust manifolds, and a {{Convert|48|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} twin-bore throttle body from the 5.7 L [[GM Small-Block engine]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.roadandtrack.com/car-culture/classic-cars/a26217/1992-gmc-typhoon-first-drive-flashback/|title=1992 GMC Typhoon: First Drive Flashback|date=2015-07-30|work=Road & Track|access-date=2018-07-25|language=en-US}} The Typhoon sends power to all four wheels through a 4L60 4-speed [[automatic transmission]] and a [[BorgWarner]] 4472 (the Syclone used a BorgWarner 1372){{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} transfer case splitting torque with 35% forward and 65% to the rear wheels. Other features include upgraded brakes, a limited slip rear differential and sport modifications to the standard suspensions. Unlike the Syclone, the Typhoon featured an air-operated [[Self-levelling suspension|self-leveling rear suspension]].{{cite web |last1=Huizenga |first1=Paul |title=Storm on the Horizon: Tracing Today's Super SUV Origins |url=https://www.drivingline.com/articles/storm-on-the-horizon-tracing-todays-super-suv-origins/ |website=Driving Line |publisher=Nitto Tire |accessdate=19 December 2019}} During tests by ''[[Car and Driver]],'' the Typhoon was capable of accelerating from {{convert|0|–|60|mph|abbr=on}} in 5.3 seconds and could do a quarter-mile run in 14.1 seconds at {{convert|95|mph|abbr=on}}. ''[[Car and Driver]]'' compared the Syclone's performance favorably to the [[Ferrari 348]]ts, [[Chevrolet Corvette]], and [[Nissan 300ZX|Nissan 300ZX Turbo]]. It cost {{USD}}29,970, though the magazine criticized the plastic interior pieces. ==Production and colors== All three model years were built for GMC by [[Production Automotive Services]] of [[Troy, Michigan|Troy]], [[Michigan]]. Aside from a handful of prototypes, only 4,697 Typhoons were built by GMC: 2,497 for 1992, and 2,200 for 1993. Unlike regular production Syclones, Typhoons were offered in various color configurations that differed by year, with black/black being the most common. '''1991''' * Typhoon Pre-Production (6 total) '''1992''' * Black w/ Black (1262 total) * Black w/ Gray (130 total) * Frost White w/ Gray (518 total) * Apple Red w/ Gray (345 total) * Bright Teal w/ Gray (132 total) * Forest Green Metallic w/ Gray (82 total) * Aspen Blue w/ Gray (28 total) * Radar Blue w/ Radar Blue (2 total{{efn|name=fnRR|These factory test colors are included in the totals of the seven original color combinations.}}) * Raspberry Metallic w/ Raspberry Metallic (2 total{{efn|name=fnRR}}) '''1993''' * Black w/ Black (1,008 total) * Black w/ Gray (98 total) * Frost White w/ White (532 total{{efn|Total includes 1 Radar Blue w/ Radar Blue factory test color truck.}}) * Frost White w/ Gray (115 total) * Apple Red w/ Apple Red (77 total) * Apple Red w/ Gray (101 total) * Forest Green Metallic w/ Gray (210 total) * Garnet Red w/ Gray (24 total) * Royal Blue Metallic w/ Gray (35 total) ==Notable owners== *[[Clint Eastwood]] has owned a Typhoon.{{cite web| url= http://www.roadandtrack.com/car-culture/videos/a30702/clint-eastwood-drives-a-gmc-typhoon/ | magazine=[[Road & Track]]| date= September 7, 2016| title= Clint Eastwood Drives a GMC Typhoon| first= Travis| last= Okulski | access-date= July 6, 2017}} *[[John F. Kennedy Jr.]] owned a Typhoon which was stolen and recovered in 1998.{{cite news| url= http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/gossip/saab-story-joyride-john-jr-article-1.810622 | title= From Saab Story To Joyride for John Jr.| first1= George | last1= Rush | first2= Joanna | last2= Molloy | first3= Marcus | last3= Baram | first4= K.C. | last4= Baker| newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]| date= October 23, 1998 | access-date= July 6, 2017 }}{{cite news| url= https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/nyregion/kennedy-s-stolen-vehicle-is-recovered.html| newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| title= Kennedy's Stolen Vehicle Is Recovered | date= November 27, 1996 | access-date= July 6, 2017}} * According to a story told by [[Jeremy Clarkson]], [[Bob Seger]] owned one as his daily driver during the 1990s.{{cite web| url= https://www.topgear.com/car-news/jeremy-clarkson/clarkson-bob-seger | work= Top Gear Magazine| date= 5 December 1994| title= Clarkson on: Bob Seger | first= Jeremy| last= Clarkson | access-date= March 14, 2018 | publisher= [[BBC]] }} ==Notes== {{notelist}} == See also == * [[GMC Syclone]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|GMC Typhoon}} *[http://www.internationalsytyregistry.com/ SyTyRegistry] *[http://www.instagram.com/internationalsytyregistry/ ISTR Instagram] *[http://www.sportmachines.com/ Syclone, Typhoon, Sonoma GT Database & History] *[http://www.sportmachines.net/ Sportmachines - Syclone, Typhoon, Sonoma GT Restoration & Parts] {{GMC}} [[Category:GMC vehicles|Typhoon]] [[Category:Sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Mid-size sport utility vehicles]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1991]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

Chevrolet | unit_cost = | production_date =1942–1945 | number = 21,147{{cite web|url=http://www.transchool.eustis.army.mil/Museum/DUKW.htm|title=DUKW|publisher=US Army Transportation Museum |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725043610/http://www.transchool.eustis.army.mil/Museum/DUKW.htm |archivedate= 2008-07-25}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=MuGsf0psjvcC&pg=PA67 |title=The Encyclopedia of Weapons of WWII|last=Bishop |first=Chris |page=67 |year=2002 |publisher=Sterling Publishing Company |isbn=1-58663-762-2 |accessdate=2010-03-24}} | variants = | spec_label=Yellow, 1942{{cite book|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/156960441/TM-9-802-GMC-DUKW-353|title=TM 9-802 {{frac|2|1|2}} ton Amphibian Truck, 6x6, GMC DUKW-353|date=1943|accessdate=24 Oct 2016|publisher=US War Dept.|isbn=|pp=8–9}} | weight={{convert|13,600|lb|abbr=on}} empty | length={{convert|31|ft|m|2|abbr=on}} | width={{convert|8|ft|m|2|abbr=on}} | height={{convert|8|ft|10|in|m|2|abbr=on}} with top up
{{convert|7|ft|1|in|m|2|abbr=on}} minimum | payload_capacity={{convert|5,000|lb|abbr=on}} or 24 troops | primary_armament=Ring mount for .50BMG fitted to 25% DUKWs | secondary_armament= | armour= | suspension= Live axles on leaf springs | speed={{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} on road,
{{convert|6.4|mph|kn km/h|abbr=on|0}} in water {{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} | vehicle_range={{convert|400|mi|abbr=on}} on road | engine=GMC Model 270 | engine_power={{convert|91|hp|kW|abbr=on}}{{cite book|last=Doyle|first=David|title=Standard catalog of U.S. Military Vehicles|year=2003|publisher=[[Krause Publications]]|lccn=|isbn=0-87349-508-X|p=121|authorlink=David Doyle (writer)}} | pw_ratio= | crew=1 }} The '''DUKW''' (colloquially known as '''Duck''') is a six-wheel-drive [[amphibious vehicle|amphibious]] modification of the {{frac|2|1|2}}-ton [[CCKW]] trucks used by the U.S. military during [[World War II]] and the [[Korean War]]. Designed by a partnership under military auspices of [[Sparkman & Stephens]] and [[GMC (automobile)|General Motors Corporation]] (GMC), the DUKW was used for the transportation of goods and troops over land and water. Excelling at approaching and crossing beaches in amphibious warfare attacks, it was intended only to last long enough to meet the demands of combat. Surviving DUKWs have since found popularity as tourist craft in marine environments. ==Etymology== The name '''DUKW''' comes from General Motors Corporation model [[nomenclature]]:{{cite book|title=Michigan Manufacturer and Financial Record|volume=73|year=1944|publisher=Manufacturer Publishing Co.|page=104}} * '''D''', Designed in 1942 * '''U''', [[Utility vehicle|Utility]] * '''K''', [[All-wheel drive]] * '''W''', Dual-tandem rear axles Decades later, the designation was [[backronym|explained erroneously]] by writers such as Donald Clarke, who wrote in 1978 that it was an initialism for "Duplex Universal Karrier, Wheeled".{{cite book|last=Clarke|first=Donald|title=How It Works: The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Science and Technology|volume=1|year=1978|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|page=96}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LcidHt4zzDgC&pg=PA109 |page=109 |title=Ironsides: Canadian Armoured Fighting Vehicle Museums and Monuments |last=Skaarup |first=Harold A. |publisher=iUniverse |year=2011 |isbn=1462034640}} ==History== The DUKW was designed by Rod Stephens, Jr. of [[Sparkman & Stephens]], Inc. yacht designers, [[Dennis Puleston]], a British deep-water sailor resident in the U.S., and Frank W. Speir from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].{{cite web |url=http://www.foils.org/miami.htm |title=Miami Shipbuilding Corporation |publisher=Foils.org |accessdate=2013-12-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816122208/http://www.foils.org/miami.htm |archive-date=2014-08-16 |url-status=dead }} Developed by the [[National Defense Research Committee]] and the [[Office of Scientific Research and Development]] to solve the problem of resupply to units which had just performed an amphibious landing, it was initially rejected by the armed services. When a [[United States Coast Guard]] patrol craft ran aground on a sand bar near [[Provincetown, Massachusetts]], an experimental DUKW happened to be in the area for a demonstration. Winds up to {{convert|60|knots}}, rain, and heavy surf prevented conventional craft from rescuing the seven stranded Coast Guardsmen, but the DUKW had no trouble,{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=119}} and military opposition to the DUKW melted. The DUKW later proved its seaworthiness by crossing the [[English Channel]]. The final production design was perfected by a few engineers at Yellow Truck & Coach in Pontiac, Michigan. The vehicle was built by [[Yellow Coach Manufacturing Company|Yellow Truck and Coach Co.]] ([[GMC (automobile)|GMC Truck and Coach Div.]] after 1943) at their [[Pontiac West Assembly|Pontiac West Assembly Plant]] and [[Chevrolet|Chevrolet Div.]] of [[General Motors|General Motors Corp.]] at their [[St. Louis Truck Assembly|St. Louis Truck Assembly Plant]]; 21,147 were manufactured before production ended in 1945.{{sfnp|Doyle|2003|pp=119}} ==Description== [[File:Aa edencamp dukw.jpg|thumb|left|DUKW at the [[Eden Camp]] museum, England]] The DUKW was built around the GMC AFKWX, a [[Cab Over Engine|cab-over-engine]] (COE) version of the [[GMC CCKW]] six-wheel-drive military truck, with the addition of a watertight hull and a propeller. It was powered by a {{convert|269.5|cuin|l|0|abbr=on}} [[GMC Straight-6 engine|GMC]] Model 270 [[straight-six engine]]. A five-speed overdrive transmission drove a [[transfer case]] for the propeller, then a two-speed transfer case to drive the axles. The propeller and front axle were selectable from their transfer case. A [[power take-off]] on the transmission drove an air-compressor and winch.{{sfnp|TM 9-802|1942|pp=3, 8}} It weighed {{convert|13,000|lb|abbr=on}} empty and operated at {{convert|50|mph|km/h}} on road and {{convert|5.5|kn|mph km/h}} on water.{{cite book|last=Friedman |first=Norman |title=U.S. amphibious ships and craft: an illustrated design history |publisher=Naval Institute Press |year=2002 |series=Illustrated Design Histories |page=218 |isbn=1-55750-250-1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=oWX-x0b4pw4C&pg=PA218&lpg=PA218 |accessdate=March 22, 2010 }} It was {{convert|31|ft|2}} long, {{convert|8|ft|3|in|m|2}} wide, {{convert|7|ft|2|in|m|2}} high with the folding-canvas top down and {{convert|8|ft|9|in|m|2}} high with the top up.[[File:FLMM - DUKW 353 aft.jpg|thumb|Rear view of a DUKW preserved at the Fort Lewis Military Museum, Washington. The propeller tunnel, propeller, and rudder can be seen (2009)]] It was not an armored vehicle, being plated with sheet steel between {{convert|1/16|and|1/8|in|mm}} thick to minimize weight. A high-capacity [[bilge pump]] system kept it afloat if the thin hull was breached by holes up to {{convert|2|in|mm}} in diameter. One in four DUKWs mounted a [[M2 Browning machine gun|{{not a typo|.50-caliber}} Browning heavy machine gun]] on a ring mount.Fitzsimons, Bernard, general editor. ''The Illustrated Encyclopedia of 20th Century Weapons and Warfare'' (London: Phoebus, 1978), Vol. 8, p.802, "DUKW". The DUKW was the first vehicle to allow the driver [[Central Tire Inflation System|to vary the tire pressure from inside the cab]]. The tires could be fully inflated for hard surfaces such as roads and less inflated for softer surfaces, especially beach sand.{{sfnp|TM 9-802|1942|pp=8, 24, 35}} This added to its versatility as an amphibious vehicle. This feature is now standard on many military vehicles.{{cite book|last=Ware|first=Pat|title=The Illustrated Guide to Military Vehicles |year=2014|publisher=Hermes House| isbn=978-1-78214-192-1|pp=105, 114, 179, 244}} ==Service history== === World War II === [[File:A British DUKW carries supplies and American paratroopers across the Waal river at Nijmegen, 30 September 1944. B10434.jpg|thumb|A British DUKW carries American airborne troops and supplies across the [[River Waal]] at [[Nijmegen]], 30 September 1944]] The DUKW was supplied to the U.S. Army, U.S. Marine Corps and Allied forces, and 2,000 were supplied to Britain under the [[Lend-Lease]] program;{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/history/microsites/H/history/a-b/battletwo03.html|title=Battle Stations II: The 'Duck'|publisher=Channel 4}} 535 were acquired by Australian forces, and 586 were supplied to the Soviet Union, which built its own version, the [[BAV 485]], after the war. DUKWs were initially sent to [[Guadalcanal]] in the [[Pacific Ocean theater of World War II|Pacific Theater]], but were used by an invasion force for the first time in the [[European theatre of World War II|European theater]], during the Sicilian invasion, [[Operation Husky]], in the Mediterranean. They were used on the [[D-Day]] beaches of [[Invasion of Normandy|Normandy]] and in the [[Battle of the Scheldt]], [[Operation Veritable]], and [[Operation Plunder]]. In the Pacific, USMC DUKW's were used to cross the coral reefs of islands such as [[Saipan]] and [[Guam]] and the tires were not affected by the coral.p. 26 ''The Marines in the Pacific War'' ''The Marine Corps Gazette'', Volume 31 Marine Corps Association, 1947 Some DUKWs used in WW2 were reported to have capsized while landing at Omaha beach during the Normandy invasion.{{cite book|author1=Williamson Murray|author2=Allan Reed Millett|title=A War To Be Won: fighting the Second World War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tdYkMPfUSUAC&pg=PA422|date=30 June 2009|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-04130-1|pages=422–}}{{cite book|author=Richard Collier|title=D-Day: June 6, 1944: The Normandy Landings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qEgOkEydIQgC|date=1 November 2002|publisher=Orion Books Limited|isbn=978-0-297-84346-7}} ===After the war=== After World War II, reduced numbers were kept in service by the United States, Britain, France, and Australia, with many stored pending disposal. Australia transferred many to [[Australian Army Reserve|Citizens Military Force]] units. The U.S. Army reactivated and deployed several hundred at the outbreak of the [[Korean War]] with the 1st Transportation Replacement Training Group providing crew training. DUKWs were used extensively to bring supplies ashore during the [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter]] and in the [[Battle of Incheon|amphibious landings at Incheon]]. Ex-U.S. Army DUKWs were transferred to the French military after World War II and were used by the [[Troupes de marine]] and [[Naval commandos (France)|naval commandos]]. Many were used for general utility duties in [[Overseas departments and territories of France|overseas territories]]. France deployed DUKWs to [[French Indochina]] during the [[First Indochina War]]. Some French DUKWs were given new hulls in the 1970s, with the last being retired in 1982. Britain deployed DUKWs to Malaya during the [[Malayan Emergency]] of 1948–60. Many were redeployed to [[Borneo]] during the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation]] of 1962–66. ===Later military use=== The [[Royal Marines]] used five of these vehicles for training at 11 (Amphibious Trials and Training) Squadron, 1 Assault Group Royal Marines at [[Instow]], North Devon. Four were manufactured between 1943 and 1945. The fifth is a DUKW hull copy manufactured in 1993 with unused World War II-vintage running gear parts.{{cite web |url=http://articles.janes.com/articles/jdu99/UK-DUKWS-REFURBISHED-FOR-ROYAL-MARINES.html |title=UK DUKWS Refurbished for Royal Marines, Upgrade Update |author= |date=30 July 1999 |work=Jane's International Defence Review |publisher=Jane's Information Group |accessdate=31 August 2012}} In 1999, a refurbishment programme began to extend their service life to 2014. DUKWs were removed from service in 2012. The DUKWs were used for safety, allowing all ranks to undertake training drills for boat work for the landing craft ranks, and drivers undertaking wading drills from the [[Landing Craft Utility]]. ===Principal military users=== *{{flagicon|USA}} United States *{{flagicon|AUS}} Australia – 535 *{{flagicon|BRA}} Brazil *{{flagicon|CAN}} Canada – approximately 800 *{{flagicon|DOM}} Dominican Republic *{{flagicon|FRA}} France *{{flagicon|PHI}} Philippines *{{flagicon|IRQ}} Iraq *{{flagicon|USSR}} Soviet Union – 586 *{{flagicon|GBR}} United Kingdom – approximately 2,000 ==Developments== [[File:DUKW-353_USArmyTransportationMuseum_DSCN7534.JPG|thumb|Superduck prototype]] In the latter 1940s and throughout the 1950s, while Speir, now project engineer for the Army's Amphibious Warfare Program, worked on "bigger and better" amphibious vehicles such as the "Super Duck", the "Drake", and the mammoth [[LARC-LX|BARC]] (Barge, Amphibious, Resupply, Cargo), many DUKWs were made surplus and used as rescue vehicles by fire departments and Coast Guard stations. In 1952, the Soviet Union produced a derivative, the [[BAV 485]], adding a rear loading ramp. The [[ZiL|Zavod imeni Stalina]] factory built it on the structure of its ZiS-151 truck, and production continued until 1962, with over 2,000 units delivered. ==Civilian use== [[Image:mobyduck.jpg|right|thumb|The "Moby Duck" at a parade in Seattle (2006)]] Many were used after WWII by civilian organizations such as the police, fire departments, and rescue units. The Australian Army lent two DUKWs and crew to [[Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions]] for a 1948 expedition to [[Macquarie Island]]. Australian DUKWs were used on Antarctic supply voyages until 1970.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/dmo/news/ontarget/nov06/rw.cfm |title=Remember when ... we sent amphibious trucks to the Antarctic? |publisher=Defence Materiel Organisation |date=November 2006 |accessdate=2008-10-13 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201193633/http://www.defence.gov.au/dmo/news/ontarget/nov06/rw.cfm |archivedate=2008-12-01 }} From 1945 to 1965, the Australian Commonwealth Lighthouse Service supply ship ''Cape York'' carried ex-Army DUKWs for supplying [[lighthouse]]s on remote islands.{{citation|title=Cape Rochon – An Island Light|last=Johnson|first=Erika|publisher=Lighthouses of Australia Bulletin|volume=9|number=2|year=2006}} One DUKW is in use by the [[Technisches Hilfswerk]] (THW) of [[Germersheim]] in [[Germany]], a [[Emergency management|civil protection]] organisation.{{cite web|url=http://www.thw-germersheim.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=230&Itemid=121 |title=Ortsverband Gemersheim |publisher=Thw-germersheim.de |date= |accessdate=2013-12-27}} ==Tourist attractions== {{Main|Duck tour}} DUKWs are still in use as [[tourism|tourist]] transport in harbor and river cities across the globe, and have been associated with a number of [[Duck tour#Fatal incidents|fatal accidents]]. The first "duck tour" company was started in 1946{{cite web|url=http://www.wisconsinducktours.com/about-us/history/timeline |title=Timeline |publisher=Original Wisconsin Ducks |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}} by Mel Flath in [[Wisconsin Dells, Wisconsin]]. The company is still in operation under the name Original Wisconsin Ducks. ==See also== * [[Ford GPA]] – 4 wheel amphibious jeep * ''[[Landwasserschlepper]]'' * [[PTS (amphibious vehicle)|PTS]] * [[BAV 485|ZiS-485]] * [[GAZ 46]] * [[Terrapin (amphibious vehicle)]] – a contemporary British equivalent vehicle * [[Su-Ki]] – a contemporary Japanese equivalent vehicle * [[LARC-V]] * [[Landing Vehicle Tracked]] – tracked supply and combat amphibious vehicle * [[List of U.S. military vehicles by supply catalog designation]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite book|title=TM 9-1802A Ordnance Maintenance Power Plant for {{frac|2|1|2}}-Ton Truck 6 x 6 (GMC)|publisher=United States Department of War|date=July 1943}} * {{cite book|title=TM 9-1802B Ordnance Maintenance Power Plant for {{frac|2|1|2}}-Ton Amphibian Truck, 6 x 6 (GMC DUKW-353)|publisher=United States Department of War|date=November 1943}} * {{cite book|title=TM 9-1802C Ordnance Maintenance Hull and Water Drive for {{frac|2|1|2}}-Ton 6 x 6 Amphibian Truck, (GMC DUKW-353)|publisher=United States Department of War|date=December 1943}} * {{cite book|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/188375301/TM-9-2800-1947|title=TM 9-2800 Military Vehicles|publisher=US Dept. of the Army|date=27 Oct 1947|page=321|accessdate=24 Oct 2016}} ;Technical Manuals{{Clarify|section|date=October 2009}} * TM 9-1825A * TM 9-1826C * TM 9-1827B * TM 9-1827C * TM 9-1828A * TM 9-1829A ==External links== {{commons|DUKW}} *[http://members.aol.com/twodukw/twodukw.htm Marine Corps DUKWs in World War II] *[http://www.sparkmanstephens.com/ Sparkman & Stephens]: the company at which Rod Stephens, Jr., one of the DUKW's designers, worked (see also [https://web.archive.org/web/20060908162740/http://www.sparkmanstephens.com/gallery/dukw_pic.html this photo] with explanatory caption, on the S&S site) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071128092021/http://pages.prodigy.net/deanspeir/dukws%26lace.html Lace and DUKWs ... both part of the Speir Family legacy], several photos, statistics, and a few details of Speir's tire inflation system from his son Dean Speir *[http://cgsc.cdmhost.com/u?/p4013coll9,397 DUKW: its operation and uses] {{US military utility vehicles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dukw}} revision.comment: Alter: publisher, title. Add: date. Removed accessdate with no specified URL. | You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]].| Activated by [[User:Chris Capoccia]] | [[Category:Pages using citations with accessdate and no URL]].
